content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the situation strategically to maximize my earnings over 75 rounds. The strategy here is called the Tit-for-Tat strategy. In this game, if I always choose R (Cooperate) on the first round, and then mimic the opponent's choice from the previous round in subsequent ones (Reciprocity), the outcome should be profitable.

If my opponent starts with R, I will earn 45$ in the first round. If they switch to B in the second round, I will reciprocate with B in the third round, earning 40$. If they switch back to R, I will reciprocate again with R and so on. This way, I will earn a total of (75-1)*40 + 45 = $2960 in 75 rounds.

If my opponent starts with B, I will initially choose R for the first round to maximize my immediate payoff, earning 40$. In the following rounds, if they continue with B, I will reciprocate with B and earn 20$ each time. If my opponent switches to R at some point, I will also switch to R and earn 45$. The overall earnings in this case would be (Number of times they choose R - 1) * (45 + 20) + (Number of times they choose B - 74) * 20.

Considering the opponent's behavior is uncertain, it's hard to predict which scenario will occur more frequently. However, given that the total earnings in either case are positive and the strategy involves mimicking the opponent while ensuring a reasonable payoff for myself, I would choose R (Cooperate) as my initial move, appending it as {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the following round, since my opponent chose R in the previous round and I reciprocated with R to maximize the immediate payoff, I will mimic their choice from the previous round as well.

I choose R (Cooperate) again, appending it as {R}. Now we have moved to Round 2 of the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this case, my opponent initially cooperated with me but switched to a defection strategy in the second round. To maintain the reciprocity I aimed for in the Tit-for-Tat strategy, I should defect against their choice from the previous round.

I choose B (Defect) as my move, appending it as {B}. This way, if my opponent decides to continue with their defection strategy, my payoff will be 40$ in each subsequent round that they play B. If they switch back to R, I will cooperate and earn 45$.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent cooperated with me in the first round, I defected against their choice in the second round. However, they have now chosen R (Cooperate) in the third round. To maintain reciprocity in the Tit-for-Tat strategy, I should cooperate with their current choice.

I choose R (Cooperate), appending it as {R}. Now we are moving on to Round 3 of the game.
